channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a strong majority to help him pass bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters displayed on Tuesday in Allex, a village in southeastern France.

item.title: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
item.description: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barbara Skrobol visiting the grave of her sister-in-law Izabela Sajbor and her unborn child at a cemetery in Cwiklice, Poland.

item.title: ‘We Buried Him and Kept Walking’: Children Die as Somalis Flee Hunger
item.description: The worst drought in four decades, and a sharp rise in food prices caused by the war in Ukraine, have left almost half of Somalia’s people facing acute food shortages.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Malin Fezehai
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryam Feisal, a severely malnourished child who also contracted measles, with her mother, Mulki Abdulkadir, at the pediatric stabilization center at the Benadir Hospital in Mogadishu, last month.

item.title: A Restored Painting Recalls the Colosseum’s Christian Past
item.description: The restoration of a wall painting depicting an idealized Jerusalem is a reminder that the Roman monument, known best for gladiatorial combat, was a sacred Christian space for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Francesco Lastrucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome’s Colosseum is best known as a site of ancient gladiator spectacles, but later in its history, it was a Christian holy site.

item.title: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a strong majority to help him pass bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters displayed on Tuesday in Allex, a village in southeastern France.

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Could Soon Encircle Ukrainian Troops in Sievierodonetsk
item.description: A Ukrainian official said that Russian forces could cut off the eastern city within days. Capturing the city would give President Vladimir Putin a key victory in his bid to control all of the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a Ukrainian service member, Ihor Ivanovych Slavhorodsky, 58, in Bucha, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: China Won’t Hesitate to Fight for Taiwan, Defense Minister Warns
item.description: The general said China wouldn’t “flinch from the cost” of defending its claims to the island. He spoke at a Singapore forum where he met with the U.S. defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Roslan Rahman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: China will “resolutely smash any schemes for Taiwan independence,” its defense minister, Gen. Wei Fenghe, said at a conference in Singapore on Sunday.

item.title: Rumbling Through Modern Jordan, a Railway From the Past
item.description: Once an ambitious project to unite the Middle East, the antique Hejaz Railway is a relic of that bygone dream before wars, borders and more advanced modes of transport rendered its services obsolete.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Asmaa al-Omar and Laura Boushnak

item.title: Newly United, French Left Hopes to Counter President in Upcoming Vote
item.description: Left-wing parties have joined forces ahead of France’s two-stage parliamentary elections, hoping to revive their fortunes and put a break on President Emmanuel Macron’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Candidates meeting with farmers in the Drôme, a French region where leftist politicians believe they can win legislative seats in a push to stymie President Emmanuel Macron’s agenda.

item.title: Recording India’s Linguistic Riches as Leaders Push Hindi as Nation’s Tongue
item.description: Ganesh Devy has spent decades documenting India’s hundreds of distinct languages. Up next: a 12,000-year history of India he hopes will help counter the government’s Hindu-first campaign.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ganesh Narayan Devy has spearheaded an enormous scholarly effort to chronicle India’s rich linguistic diversity.

item.title: Shortage of Artillery Ammunition Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
item.description: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank firing at Russian positions on Friday in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine. Ammunition shortages are forcing troops to substitute tanks for howitzers.

item.title: For South Africa’s Leader, Being a Burglary Victim Spells Trouble
item.description: After a fortune in cash was stolen from President Cyril Ramaphosa’s farmhouse, he kept it secret. Now that word is out, critics ask what he was hiding.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Rodger Bosch/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa was questioned about the burglary during a rare news conference on Friday.

item.title: U.K. Officials Won’t Investigate Political Donation Flagged for Russian Origins
item.description: A bank alert had said a $630,225 Conservative Party donation originated in a Russian account. The authorities say there’s no evidence that a crime was committed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Phil Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaking at the Conservative Party’s spring conference in March in Blackpool, Britain.

item.title: Single Cigarettes in Canada Will Be Inscribed With Warning
item.description: Cigarette boxes and packaging in Canada are also expected to see an expanded list of health effects related to smoking.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Carolyn Bennett, Canada’s minister of mental health and addictions, and Dr. Hassan Mir, a cardiologist at the University of Ottawa Heart Institute, explaining expanded cigarette warnings during a news conference in Ottawa on Friday.

item.title: The Scene at the Border
item.description: We break down why border crossings are so high and who’s trying to come to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adults and children at Senda de Vida, a sprawling migrant shelter in Reynosa, Mexico, on the banks of the Rio Grande.

item.title: Coming From Separate Worlds in Taiwan, They Collided at California Church
item.description: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geneva Presbyterian Church in Laguna Woods, Calif., where members of the Irvine Taiwanese Presbyterian Church were meeting when the shooting occurred.

item.title: Momentum in Ukraine Is Shifting in Russia’s Favor
item.description: With the Ukrainians running short of guns and ammunition, and pressures growing on Western governments, Moscow’s fortunes may be rising.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives, neighbors and friends paying respect to a fallen Ukrainian soldier on Saturday in Bucha, Ukraine. At least 100 Ukrainian soldiers are dying every day under intense Russian artillery fire.

item.title: Protests Over Prophet Muhammad Comments Turn Deadly in India
item.description: Two young protesters were killed in eastern India on Friday amid demonstrations by Muslims across South Asia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Ritesh Shukla/Reuters
item.media:description: Muslim protestors threw stones at the police on Friday in Prayagraj, India. Demonstrations across the country were set off by remarks that some Muslims found offensive.

item.title: A Caravan of Migrants Is Heading Toward the U.S. Border
item.description: Some 6,000 migrants, many of them from Venezuela, set off from southern Mexico last week as leaders from across the Americas met in Los Angeles to discuss issues including migration.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Traffic-Clogged North England Bitter Over Stalled Rail Plan
item.description: Transport problems are just one symptom of the economic neglect that has long hobbled the region, where growth, employment and health care mostly lag far behind the south.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times

item.title: The Phone Booth of the Mind
item.description: Phone booths may be obsolete, but they still offer a good model for keeping our phones from taking over our lives.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: ‘A Mass Invasion of Privacy’ but No Penalties for Tim Hortons
item.description: A scathing report by four privacy commissioners found that the coffee and doughnut chain collected data on customers’ daily lives.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: “What happened in Tim Hortons is also happening elsewhere,” Daniel Therrien, the federal privacy commissioner, said.

item.title: Biden Races to Expand Coalition Against Russia but Meets Resistance
item.description: Many Asian, African and Latin American nations are maintaining ties with Russia as the United States tries to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin and end the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil met on Thursday in Los Angeles. Brazil has continued to import fertilizer from Russia and Belarus, an ally of Moscow.

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Emma Bubola

item.title: Reforms Are Imposed on U.N. Agency That Made Questionable Investments
item.description: After a New York Times report revealed unusual investments putting tens of millions of dollars at risk, the board of the U.N.’s Office for Project Services demanded major changes.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and David Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Eugene Gologursky/Getty Images
item.media:description: Grete Faremo, left, and Vitaly Vanshelboim, center, at a 2016 event with Dominica’s ambassador to the United Nations. Ms. Faremo resigned in May as the top official at the U.N.’s Office for Project Services; Mr. Vanshelboim, who was her deputy, is on administrative leave.

item.title: Jeanine Añez, Former Bolivian President, Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
item.description: The trial of Jeanine Añez, who took power after Evo Morales was ousted, has led to concerns about politicians’ use of the justice system to target opponents.
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky and María Silvia Trigo
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeanine Añez, center, assumed the presidency of Bolivia in 2019 after the ouster of Evo Morales.

item.title: McDonald’s Is Reinvented in Russia as the Economy Stumbles On
item.description: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Workers at a former McDonald’s location prepared to reopen the restaurant under a new brand on Friday in Podolsk, outside Moscow.

item.title: C.D.C. Dismisses Airborne Transmission of Monkeypox. Some Experts Disagree.
item.description: The virus “is not known to linger in the air,” agency officials said. But the research is far from definitive.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Freya Kaulbars/Rki Robert Koch Institute, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Most experts agree that the monkeypox virus does not spread far through the air. But some scientists believe airborne transmission can occur.

item.title: Behind Enemy Lines, Scouts Help Ukrainians Execute Deadly Strikes
item.description: A nascent insurgency made up of civilians or former soldiers provided information that aided Ukraine’s attack on two Russian bases, according to a senior Ukrainian military official.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: This image was taken during a media tour organized by the Russian Army, and shows Russian servicemen standing guard near the Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Plant on the Dnieper River in Kakhovka, near Kherson, last month.

item.title: Royal Shipwreck From 1682 Is Found Off the Coast of England
item.description: The Gloucester, which was carrying a future king of England when it ran aground, was found 15 years ago. Its discovery was revealed this week.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Norfolk Historic Shipwrecks, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The brothers Julian and Lincoln Barnwell measuring a cannon, part of the shipwreck of the Gloucester, in 2007.

item.title: U.S. Warns China on Taiwan as Defense Officials Meet to Cool Tensions
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III accused Beijing of “provocative” activity near the disputed island after meeting with his Chinese counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Caroline Chia/Reuters
item.media:description: Gen. Wei Fenghe, center, China’s defense minister, in Singapore on Friday before his meeting with Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III.

item.title: Pope Francis Postpones Trip to Africa, Citing Knee Problems
item.description: The postponement of the trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan comes as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be thinking of stepping down.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gregorio Borgia/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting the faithful after a prayer for peace in May in Rome.

item.title: Why the Jan. 6 Hearings Matter
item.description: Even if the Jan. 6 attack will not become a unifying moment for the country.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The House Select Committee on January 6th showed a video of former Attorney General William Barr during earlier testimony at its first public hearing on their investigation into the attack on the Capitol.

item.title: Miami-Dade, San Juan and Honolulu Have Become Covid Hot Spots
item.description: “Covid-19 hasn’t disappeared as much as our patience for precautions has,” said one public health expert.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: San Sebastian Street in San Juan, P.R., in May.

item.title: Trapped by Russian Forces, Ukrainians Waited a Month in a Basement
item.description: More than 300 Ukrainians, 77 of them children, were imprisoned in a dank and airless school basement for nearly a month. Ten of them died.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nicole Tung
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Trenches dug by Russian soldiers outside the school they used as a base, while holding more than 300 civilians prisoner in its basement throughout most of March.

item.title: When Cockatoos Become Cocka-Too Much
item.description: The native Australian birds are charismatic and deeply destructive.
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cockatoo in a eucalyptus tree at the Royal Botanic Garden in Sydney, Australia, in March.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russia and Ukraine are struggling to control “dead cities.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian regional police officers patrolling the city of Lysychansk.

item.title: Biden Faces Skepticism at Summit of the Americas
item.description: The U.S. president called for concrete commitments on several major issues, but other leaders said the United States is doing too little to meet the moment.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Miriam Jordan and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden urged “strong and constructive diplomacy” Thursday but was met with some skepticism.

item.title: U.S. and Latin American Countries Will Commit to Receive More Migrants
item.description: A joint declaration is expected to be issued Friday meant to address surging migration rates that have affected nations throughout the region.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelan migrants received food at a bus station in Medellin in 2020. Colombia is offering protected status and work permits to nearly two million Venezuelans.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Crucial Moment in the Ukraine War
item.description: Plus the U.S. begins Jan. 6 hearings and Chinese pilots provoke U.S. allies.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bridge, now destroyed by Russian forces, that once led into Sievierodonetsk.

item.title: ‘Dead Cities’ Become the Flashpoint for the Fierce War in the East
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has framed the battle in Sievierodonetsk as pivotal to the broader fight for the Donbas. Amid relentless Russian attacks, Ukraine holds on and waits for Western weapons.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett/ The New York Times
item.media:description: An unexploded Russian rocket protruded out of the pavement in the city of Lysychansk, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Begins to Dismantle Nuclear Program Cameras After Western Criticism
item.description: At a moment when experts say Iran is, again, on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb, the dismantling of U.N. cameras was a sign of worsening prospects for the 2015 deal.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran in 2010.

item.title: Biden and Bolsonaro Meet for First Time at Summit
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro addressed concerns about Brazil’s upcoming election, saying he came to power democratically and would leave office the same way.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Foreign Fighters Sentenced to Death in Russia-Held Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Legal experts said the death sentences appeared calculated to discourage foreign volunteers from joining Ukraine’s military.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Aiden Aslin, Brahim Saadoun and Shaun Pinner in a courtroom in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Dmitry Kovtun, Accused Killer of Russian Dissident, Dies at 56
item.description: He and another ex-spy were found by British authorities to have served polonium-laced tea in London to an intelligence agent who had defected.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Dmitry Serebryakov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dmitri Kovtun in 2015. Traces of polonium were found in hotel rooms and other locations that he had occupied, linking him to the murder of a fellow former spy.

item.title: U.S. Accelerated Expulsions of Haitian Migrants in May
item.description: The uptick has rekindled criticism that the Biden administration treats Black migrants differently than others, an allegation it denies.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Joseph Odelyn/Associated Press
item.media:description: Haitians who were deported from the United States arrived in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last year.

item.title: Putin Compares Himself to Peter the Great, the Famous Czar
item.description: Vladimir Putin likened his goals in Ukraine to the conquests of Peter the Great.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mikhail Metzel
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin visiting an exhibition celebrating the 350th birthday of Emperor Peter I in Moscow.

item.title: Naftali Bennett, Israel’s Prime Minister, Visits U.A.E.
item.description: The trip by Naftali Bennett, the Israeli leader, burnishes his foreign policy credentials and provides some distraction from his domestic political troubles.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: The Best Books to Read on Disinformation: Its History, Techniques and Effects
item.description: The phenomenon has undermined our trust in electoral systems, in vaccines — and in what happened at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Here are books on its history, techniques and effects.
item.dc:creator: Richard Stengel
item.category: The Misinformation Age: How False Beliefs Spread (Book)
Active Measures: The Secret History of Disinformation and Political Warfare (Book)

item.title: Russia Prosecuting 1,100 Captured Ukrainian Soldiers
item.description: Announcing the invasion in February, Vladimir Putin said Ukrainians would be prosecuted for “blood crimes.” Moscow is now making good on that vow.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers who had been fighting in the Azovstal steel plant after surrendering to Russian-backed forces last month.

item.title: The Racist Researcher Cited in the Buffalo Gunman’s Manifesto
item.description: The work of Michael Woodley, a Briton who was cited by the teenager who killed 10 Black people at a supermarket in Buffalo, included pseudoscientific theories that have been used to justify racism.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert

item.title: Tourist Damages Rome’s Spanish Steps by Pushing a Scooter Down Them
item.description: An American woman and her companion caused $27,000 in damage to the landmark, officials said. They were fined and have been barred from the site for six months.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Riccardo Antimiani/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Spanish Steps, as seen from the Piazza di Spagna in Rome last year.

item.title: German Brewers Face ‘Unprecedented’ Beer Bottle Shortage
item.description: A nation of beer lovers is facing a shortage of bottles, partly because of the war in Ukraine. Breweries are looking to drinkers for a rescue.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bottles filled with beer in Klosterbrauerei Neuzelle’s warehouse don’t come cheap. Their price “has exploded,” the German brewery’s managing director said.

item.title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Arrested in Virus Test Kit Scandal
item.description: The health minister and the mayor of Hanoi were removed from their posts in a scandal that has led to charges against dozens of officials.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen
item.media:credit: Luong Thai Linh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Testing for covid in Hanoi. The city’s mayor and Vietnam's health minister have been removed from office and arrested over a test kit scandal.

item.title: Covid and Race
item.description: The death rate for white Americans has recently exceeded the rates for Black, Latino and Asian Americans.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clem Williams, 76, receiving her second booster shot in Durham, N.C. in May.

item.title: Chinese Pilots Sent a Message. American Allies Said They Went Too Far.
item.description: Australia and Canada said Chinese jets harassed their military planes, though Beijing says it was defending its security. A mishap over Pacific waters could have ominous repercussions.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Taiwan Ministry of Defense, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Chinese J-16 fighter jet, in an undated photo released by Taiwan’s defense ministry. Australia said a J-16 harassed one of its surveillance planes over the South China Sea last month.

item.title: A Radical Collective Takes Over One of the World’s Biggest Art Shows
item.description: Ruangrupa, an Indonesian group of collaborators, turns social experiences into art. How will they leave their mark on Documenta, which unfolds over 100 days?
item.dc:creator: Samanth Subramanian
item.media:credit: Arne Piepke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ade Darmawan (in orange), a founder of ruangrupa; Ayse Gulec, a member of Documenta’s artistic team; the artist Agus Nur Amal PMTOH (far right); and Agus’s manager, Greistina Kusumaningrum (left, back to camera) preparing for Documenta 15.

item.title: White House Outlines Covid Vaccine Plan for Children Under 5
item.description: Vaccine deliveries to U.S. states are contingent on the Food and Drug Administration authorizing pediatric doses, a step that could occur as soon as next week.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Emma H. Tobin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Federal officials said they expected many children younger than 5 to be vaccinated against the coronavirus by pediatricians and primary care physicians.
